nodes.bodyText:
I'd don't get the idea of having -1 here. Doesn't it make usage more complicated?
I thought adding the real sequence number would make incremental checkpointing easier (you just need to remember the highest number of the previous checkpoint).

Must be called after {@link #start} and before {@link #finish(long)}.

+ * @param startSeqNum is the sequence number of the 1st passed buffer + * It’s intended use is incremental snapshots + * For the restored buffers it should be -1

nodes.bodyText:
For incremental checkpointing, we need to distinguish somehow restored buffers from new buffers. Given that:

sequence numbers currently start from 0 after the restart
buffers don't carry any sequence numbers themselves
we can't compare the given argument with something from the previous run.

Can you please explain what are "real sequence numbers"?

Must be called after {@link #start} and before {@link #finish(long)}.

nodes.bodyText:
I thought about storing the sequence numbers alongside the data. But I haven't thought about sequence numbers being reset.
I'm simply not sure how incremental checkpoints should work if we don't have that information.
Let's assume there is a checkpoint where for one specific channel buffer 0..9 are stored. Now, there is a recovery where only 0..5 are completely unspilled before a new checkpoint is taken, in which 6..15 are stored. For incremental snapshot, we would simply skip storing 6..9 because at the current API, they'd get a -1. However, how would the recovery know where to resume?

+ * @param startSeqNum is the sequence number of the 1st passed buffer + * It’s intended use is incremental snapshots + * For the restored buffers it should be -1

nodes.bodyText:
I assume that by unspilling you mean sending the buffers out (to the operator or to downstream); and that we have 6 new buffers.
The other one is to count how many buffers or bytes actually are in-flight and store this offset.
One option would be to do a full snapshot if there any negative sequence numbers.
Of course, having SNs inside the buffers would simplify a lot, but I guess it would require more effort and discussion.

nodes.bodyText:
I'd probably not refer to MVP in the code. Noone from outside will know what it means.
How about Can be -2 if unknown, which will fail on incremental checkpoint.

Must be called after {@link #start} and before {@link #finish(long)}.

+ * @param startSeqNum is the sequence number of the 1st passed buffer + * It’s intended use is incremental snapshots + * For the restored buffers it should be -1 + * For MVP it can always be -2 + * If no data is passed it is ignored + */ + void addInputData(long checkpointId, InputChannelInfo info, int startSeqNum, Buffer... data); + + /** + * Add in-flight buffers from the {@link org.apache.flink.runtime.io.network.partition.ResultSubpartition ResultSubpartition}. + *

Must be called after {@link #start} and before {@link #finish(long)}.

+ * @param startSeqNum is the sequence number of the 1st passed buffer + * It’s intended use is incremental snapshots + * For the restored buffers it should be -1 + * For MVP it can always be -2 + * If no data is passed it is ignored + */ + void addOutputData(long checkpointId, ResultSubpartitionInfo info, int startSeqNum, Buffer... data); + + /** + * Finalize write of channel state for the given checkpoint id. + *

Must be called after {@link #start}.

+ */ + void finish(long checkpointId); + + /** + *

Must be called after {@link #finish}.

+ */ + Future> getWriteCompletionFuture(long checkpointId);

nodes.bodyText: Ah yes, if it does not need to be called after finish, it will be much more usable and I agree it should be separate.

nodes.bodyText: as before: How many implementation with no-op close do you expect? I'd assume it's only one and then I'd avoid having it as default implementation.

nodes.bodyText: It's confusing that we now have InputChannelID and InputChannelInfo. I don't see a good solution though. Similarly, it's a bit of a pity that we cannot reuse this class for ResultSubpartitionInfo (virtually it's the same thing). Maybe @zhijiangW has an idea.

nodes.bodyText:
Unfortunately, we can't use IDs as they are currently assigned at random. I'll put it into the javadoc.
To identify state, we logically need: source task id, target task id, isUpstream. Instead of isUpstream, I thought it's better to have an explicit entity for both InputChannel and ResultSubpartition.
Regarding names, it was actually @zhijiangW (good) idea:)

nodes.bodyText:
It indeed brings confusing for having both InputChannelID and InputChannelInfo now.
InputChannelID is the unique id for identifying while requesting partitions from different tasks on upstream side.
InputChannelInfo is a wrapper structure which would be easily extended to cover more infos (e.g. task index) future if necessary. And currently the strong requirement is to identify it for different InputGate instances.
The "inspiration" is form existing TaskInfo structure coincides with executionId. I also do not see a better solution yet.

nodes.bodyText:
InputChannelID can not be replaced directly by InputChannelInfo` as I described the function above.
For every upstream task, it can receive the partition requests from the InputChannel of different task instances. And now it uses the global unique InputChannelID for distinguishing with different tasks.
But InputChannelInfo can only guarantee the uniqueness within one task scope,  and still has the same id among different tasks, unless we introduce InputChannelID into the InputChannelInfo.

Must be called after {@link #start(long)} and before {@link #finish(long)}.

+ * @param startSeqNum is the sequence number of the 1st passed buffer. + * It’s intended use is incremental snapshots. + * For the restored buffers it should be -1.

nodes.bodyText: I am a bit confused of the description rather than received from the upstream or from the operator. I may guess your meaning, but I wonder it might confuse other guys. E.g. for previously spilled input buffers the sequence number should also be -1 during recovery.
